issue.title: feat: add test framework, address method and server ready/closed promises
issue.body:
* Adds mocha test framework
* Adds `.address()` method to `Http3Server` to know which port/host it ends up listening on
* Adds `.ready` and `closed` promises to `Http3Server` so you don't have to guess when it's ready to use

The `.address()` method is necessary to know which port a server listens on when you specify `0` as the parameter to avoid clashes during testing.

The `.ready` and `.closed` promises are triggered by callbacks from the C++ code - I hope I implemented these correctly.

I've replicated all of the tests from the current suite, these can be deleted in a follow up PR.

Because we don't have to use an arbitrary timeout to wait for the server to be ready the test suite is now much faster to run - on my machine the port is opened in 20-30ms so no need to wait 2000ms as in the current suite.

The event loop still takes a long time to shut down though, maybe this can be refactored?

Fixes #100

comment.body:
> This:
`setTimeout(() => { if (!testcheck()) { console.log('tests took too long, probably hanging') process.exit(1) } else { console.log('global event loop gone, everything alright') process.exit(0) } }, 40 * 1000)`
is actually a test.

Ah, right - I saw that but thought it was redundant considering mocha has built-in timeouts for all the tests.  I think the added `event-loop.spec.js` covers it?  It asserts that you can create an event loop, and that when you shut the event loop down, the `globalLoop` reference goes away which is what the `testcheck` function does.

commits.message:
fix: remove metrics from component (#17)

Since muxers are factories there's no point tracking stream metrics for each instance as they trample over each other, so remove the use of tracked maps in this module.

This was added to mplex by mistake and copied here, but it's since been removed from mplex so this change brings yamux in line.

pull_request.body:
Bumps [it-all](https://github.com/achingbrain/it) from 1.0.6 to 2.0.0.
Release notes

Sourced from it-all's releases.

it-all-v2.0.0

it-all-v2.0.0 (2022-10-17)

⚠ BREAKING CHANGES

  • all modules are now published as ESM-only

Features

  • convert to typescript (#28) (f8a38bf)
Commits
  • 417a1f3 chore(release): 2.0.0 [skip ci]
  • 8bd4bd2 chore: update build scripts
  • 585df8d docs: update readme
  • f8a38bf feat!: convert to typescript (#28)
  • b621056 Publish
  • da0c69f fix: use EventTarget instead of EventEmitter (#27)
  • cfc852b fix: accepts iterable also (#24)
  • c74ff5f Publish
  • 5122172 fix: update types for it-ndjson

issue.title: feat: add test framework, address method and server ready/closed promises
issue.body:
* Adds mocha test framework
* Adds `.address()` method to `Http3Server` to know which port/host it ends up listening on
* Adds `.ready` and `closed` promises to `Http3Server` so you don't have to guess when it's ready to use

The `.address()` method is necessary to know which port a server listens on when you specify `0` as the parameter to avoid clashes during testing.

The `.ready` and `.closed` promises are triggered by callbacks from the C++ code - I hope I implemented these correctly.

I've replicated all of the tests from the current suite, these can be deleted in a follow up PR.

Because we don't have to use an arbitrary timeout to wait for the server to be ready the test suite is now much faster to run - on my machine the port is opened in 20-30ms so no need to wait 2000ms as in the current suite.

The event loop still takes a long time to shut down though, maybe this can be refactored?

Fixes #100

comment.body:
> This:
`setTimeout(() => { if (!testcheck()) { console.log('tests took too long, probably hanging') process.exit(1) } else { console.log('global event loop gone, everything alright') process.exit(0) } }, 40 * 1000)`
is actually a test.

Ah, right - I saw that but thought it was redundant considering mocha has built-in timeouts for all the tests.  I think the added `event-loop.spec.js` covers it?  It asserts that you can create an event loop, and that when you shut the event loop down, the `globalLoop` reference goes away which is what the `testcheck` function does.

comment.diff_hunk:

+import { getReaderValue } from './fixtures/reader-value.js'
+import { WebTransport } from '../lib/index.js'
+import { expect } from 'chai'
+import { readStream } from './fixtures/read-stream.js'
+import { writeStream } from './fixtures/write-stream.js'
+import { defer } from '../lib/utils.js'
+
+/**
+ * @template T

+ */
+
+const SERVER_PATH = '/unidirectional-streams'
+
+describe('bidirectional streams', function () {
comment.body:
Mocha injects these into the global scope, with eslint you can put a comment at the top of the file to tell it the file is a mocha test:

```js
/* eslint-env mocha */
```

commits.message:
fix: remove metrics from component (#17)

Since muxers are factories there's no point tracking stream metrics for each instance as they trample over each other, so remove the use of tracked maps in this module.

This was added to mplex by mistake and copied here, but it's since been removed from mplex so this change brings yamux in line.

commits.message: docs: update readme to link to correct branch

feat!: add metrics (#223)

Uses new metrics interface from https://github.com/libp2p/js-libp2p-interfaces/pull/310 to report useful connection metrics.

Similar to #217 but it adds the listening host/port to the metrics name to allow multiple TCP listeners to report metrics separately.

BREAKING CHANGE: requires metrics interface v4

issue.title: feat: add test framework, address method and server ready/closed promises
issue.body:
* Adds mocha test framework
* Adds `.address()` method to `Http3Server` to know which port/host it ends up listening on
* Adds `.ready` and `closed` promises to `Http3Server` so you don't have to guess when it's ready to use

The `.address()` method is necessary to know which port a server listens on when you specify `0` as the parameter to avoid clashes during testing.

The `.ready` and `.closed` promises are triggered by callbacks from the C++ code - I hope I implemented these correctly.

I've replicated all of the tests from the current suite, these can be deleted in a follow up PR.

Because we don't have to use an arbitrary timeout to wait for the server to be ready the test suite is now much faster to run - on my machine the port is opened in 20-30ms so no need to wait 2000ms as in the current suite.

The event loop still takes a long time to shut down though, maybe this can be refactored?

Fixes #100

comment.body:
> This:
`setTimeout(() => { if (!testcheck()) { console.log('tests took too long, probably hanging') process.exit(1) } else { console.log('global event loop gone, everything alright') process.exit(0) } }, 40 * 1000)`
is actually a test.

Ah, right - I saw that but thought it was redundant considering mocha has built-in timeouts for all the tests.  I think the added `event-loop.spec.js` covers it?  It asserts that you can create an event loop, and that when you shut the event loop down, the `globalLoop` reference goes away which is what the `testcheck` function does.

commits.message:
fix: remove metrics from component (#17)

Since muxers are factories there's no point tracking stream metrics for each instance as they trample over each other, so remove the use of tracked maps in this module.

This was added to mplex by mistake and copied here, but it's since been removed from mplex so this change brings yamux in line.

pull_request.body:
Uses new metrics interface from https://github.com/libp2p/js-libp2p-interfaces/pull/310 to report useful connection metrics.

Similar to #217 but it adds the listening host/port to the metrics name to allow multiple TCP listeners to report metrics separately.

BREAKING CHANGE: requires metrics interface v4
